mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Phylogeny and systematics of the Trapeziidae Miers, 1886 (Crustacea: Brachyura), with the description of a new family

tax:ref_group.tax:p: AnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaCancridaeCancerglaberrimusspeciesHerbst, 1790: 262Cancer glaberrimus Herbst,1790:262, pl.20, fig.115 (colour) (see Plate2 C).

AnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTrapeziidaeTrapeziaserratifronsspeciesJacquinot, in Hombron & Jacquinot 1846Trapezia serratifrons Jacquinot, in Hombron & Jacquinot1846: pl.4, fig.20 (colour)—23; Jacquinot, inLucas1853:47.

tax:div.tax:p: Remarks. The taxonomic history ofAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaCancridaeCancerglaberrimusspeciesHerbst, 1790Cancer glaberrimus Herbst,1790, has been very confusing. In recent times, the name has been used loosely for a number of species ofAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetraliagenusTetralia, and despite the several revisions and taxonomic studies (including the establishment of a separate genusAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetraloidesgenusTetraloides) by several authors, the exact identity ofAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetraliaglaberrimaspeciesT. glaberrima has never been discussed. This is all the more unfortunate and surprising sinceAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaCancridaeCancerglaberrimusspeciesCancer glaberrimus is thetype species ofAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetraliagenusTetralia. In fact, as late as1918,Rathbun (1918:254) regardedAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaCancridaeCancerglaberrimusspeciesCancer glaberrimus as a junior synonym of the grapsidAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaGrapsidaePlanesminutusspeciesLinnaeus, 1758Planes minutus (Linnaeus,1758)!

Unfortunately, only its colour provides a clue to the identity ofAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaCancridaeCancerglaberrimusspeciesC. glaberrimus. The smooth carapace was described as brown with a bluish colour that gave it a porcelain­like shine ("porzellanähnliches Ansehen "; Herbst1790:262). A colour figure (Herbst1790: pl.20, fig.115) shows a large, blue spot centered on the anterior half of the carapace (Plate2 A). The spot surrounds a smaller, round spot of the same colour, perhaps a hole on the carapace. No such colour pattern has ever been observed or described in any trapeziid so it is most probably an artefact. A blue band across the frontal margin of the carapace has been described inAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetraliacinctipesspeciesPaulson, 1875T. cinctipes Paulson,1875, but this is evident only on live specimens (Castro1997 b: pl.1, fig. A [colour]), something Herbst most probably could not observe. A uniform brown colour without black or dark brown bands agrees best with the colour pattern ofAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetraliafulvaspeciesSerene, 1984T. fulvaSerène,1984 (seeCastro1997 a:67, pl.1, fig. C [colour]). As such, on the basis of the available information,AnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaCancridaeCancerglaberrimusspeciesCancer glaberrimus can be referred to eitherAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetraliacinctipesspeciesPaulson, 1875T. cinctipes Paulson,1875, orAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetraliafulvaspeciesSerene, 1984T. fulvaSerène,1984. However, we believe that in the interests of nomenclatural stability,AnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaCancridaeCancerglaberrimusspeciesC. glaberrimus andAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetraliafulvaspeciesT. fulva should be regarded as synonymous (see below). Thetype locality ofAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaCancridaeCancerglaberrimusspeciesC. glaberrimus was stated as unknown, although it was probably obtained from the Indian Ocean as much of his material was from there (seeNg1996,Sakai1999). There are no extanttype (s). The first two authors have searched in vain for thetypes on separate occasions over the last decade, andSakai (1999:41) also recorded that it was lost. This has also been confirmed by the former and present crustacean curators of the Zoologisch Museum, Humboldt­Universität, Berlin, Hans Gruner and Oliver Coleman respectively (pers. comm.).

The identity ofAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTrapeziidaeTrapeziaintegraspeciesLatreille, 1828Trapezia integraLatreille,1828, is also a mystery. There is notype material in the Muséum national d’Histoire naturelle, Paris. The species was described from an unknown location and it was seemingly a new or replacement name forAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaCancridaeCancerglaberrimusspeciesLatreille 1828: 696Cancer glaberrimus (Latreille1828:696). As such,AnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTrapeziidaeTrapeziaintegraspeciesLatreille, 1828Trapezia integraLatreille,1828, shares the sametype series asAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaCancridaeCancerglaberrimusspeciesHerbst, 1790Cancer glaberrimus Herbst,1790.

Castro (1997 b) suggested thatAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTrapeziidaeTrapeziaserratifronsspeciesJacquinot, 1846T. serratifrons Jacquinot,1846 (type locality Marquesas Islands,French Polynesia) is likely to be conspecific withAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetraliafulvaspeciesSerene, 1984T. fulvaSerène,1984. It is here regarded as a junior synonym ofAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetraliaglaberrimaspeciesT. glaberrima. The colour figure ofAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTrapeziidaeTrapeziaserratifronsspeciesT. serratifrons (which shows a brown carapace without dark bands) is diagnostic forAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetraliaglaberrimaspeciesT. glaberrima (asAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetraliafulvaspeciesT. fulva). Notype material of this species (supposedly in theMNHN) exists.

tax:ref_group.tax:p: AnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetralialaevissimaspeciesStimpson, 1858Tetralia laevissimaStimpson,1858, described from southernJapan, is very likely to be a junior synonym ofAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetraliaglaberrimaspeciesT. glaberrima as well. Although Stimpson’stype material is no longer extant, the drawings, presumably made by Stimpson himself or under his supervision (Stimpson,1907: pl.9, figs.4, 4 a), do not show any distinctive, obvious colour pattern on the carapace, chelipeds, or ambulatory legs. This is diagnostic forAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetraliafulvaspeciesT. fulva (sensuGalil1988 a: fig.1 b;Castro1997 a: pl.1, fig. C [colour]) (= presentAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetraliaglaberrimaspeciesT. glaberrima), which is uniformly brown to tan except a thin orange to red­orange line along the anterior border of the carapace and along the distal margins of carpi and anterior margins of meri of chelipeds. The ambulatory legs are uniformly brown to tan except a black spot on the articulations of the carpi visible in most specimens. We doubt that Stimpson would have missed a characteristic colour pattern such as a wide band along the anterior portion of the carapace (if present) in his figure of the species, especially since he clearly indicated the honeycomb­like network of lines in his drawing of the carapace ofAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTrapeziidaeTrapeziaseptataspeciesTrapezia septata (Stimpson1907: pl.9, fig.5, asAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTrapeziidaeTrapeziareticulataspeciesStimpson, 1858Trapezia reticulataStimpson,1858). The chelipeds ofAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetralialaevissimaspeciesT. laevissima were described as "glossy", which also agree with those ofAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetraliafulvaspeciesT. fulva. InAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetraliacinctipesspeciesPaulson, 1875T. cinctipes Paulson,1875, a species where the carapace (but not the chelipeds and ambulatory legs) is also uniformly brown to tan in preserved specimens, the chelipeds cannot be described as glossy since they are covered by small but distinct tubercles.Serène (1984) synonymisedAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetraliarubridactylaspeciesGarth, 1971T. rubridactylaGarth,1971 withAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetralialaevissimaspeciesT. laevissima without comment, an action we do not agree with.AnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetraliarubridactylaspeciesTetralia rubridactyla typically has a prominent crest along the anterior margins of the cheliped merus, and the distal edge of the cheliped merus as well as the dorsal surface of the cheliped merus and propodus are dark brown in colour when alive, characters that are clearly absent in Stimpson's figure or description. The posterior portion of the carapace ofAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetralialaevissimaspeciesT. laevissima appears very narrow, as in members ofAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetraloidesgenusTetraloides, but we believe this is due merely to the figure being schematic. A setae­filled depression on the dorsal proximal surface of the cheliped propodus, diagnostic forAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetraliagenusTetralia is absent inAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetraloidesgenusTetraloides, but is clearly indicated in Stimpson's drawings (Stimpson1907: pl.9, figs.4, 4 a).

As already discussed byCastro (1997 a:67), the nameAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetraliaglaberrimaspeciesTetralia glaberrima formaAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetraliafulvaspeciesPatton, 1966fulvaPatton,1966, is invalid under the current zoological code. Its first valid use was apparently bySerène (1984), who also used Patton's name as a subspecies,AnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetraliaglaberrimafulvasubspeciesT. glaberrima fulva. As Patton's material was no longer extant,Castro (1997 a:65) designated aneotype ofAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetraliafulvaspeciesSerene, 1984T. fulvaSerène,1984, from Queensland,Australia. It is also worthwhile to note that the first nomenclaturally valid use of "AnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetraliafulvaspeciesfulva " may in fact be byRibes (1978:14) who used the name "AnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetraliaglaberrimafulvasubspeciesTetralia glaberrima fulva " in her doctoral thesis. This thesis, however, had a very limited circulation and is not well known outsideFrance, and is not here regarded as a valid publication. Even if Ribes' thesis is considered a valid publication (as might be shown later), it will not affect the taxonomy of the species because on the basis of the present studyAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetraliaglaberrimafulvasubspeciesTetralia glaberrima fulva is an objective junior synonym ofAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaCancridaeCancerglaberrimusspeciesHerbst, 1790Cancer glaberrimus Herbst,1790 (see below).

tax:div.tax:p: Castro (1997 a:68) had shown thatAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetraliasanguineomaculataspeciesGalil & Clark, 1990T. sanguineomaculataGalil & Clark,1990 (type localityNew Caledonia), is a junior subjective synonym ofAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetraliafulvaspeciesT. fulva.

The recognition of the poorly understoodAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaCancridaeCancerglaberrimusspeciesHerbst, 1790C. glaberrimus Herbst,1790, as a senior synonym ofAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetraliafulvaspeciesSerene, 1984Tetralia fulvaSerène,1984,AnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTrapeziidaeTrapeziaintegraspeciesLatreille, 1828Trapezia integraLatreille,1828,AnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTrapeziidaeTrapeziaserratifronsspeciesJacquinot, 1846Trapezia serratifrons Jacquinot,1846, andAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetralialaevissimaspeciesStimpson, 1858Tetralia laevissimaStimpson,1858, does not cause any problems. The name and taxonomic concept ofAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetraliafulvaspeciesTetralia fulva was only established with certainty relatively recently (Galil1988 a) and the name has been seldom used. In any case, as discussed earlier,AnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetraliafulvaspeciesSerene, 1984Tetralia fulvaSerène,1984, has to be replaced byAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTrapeziidaeTrapeziaintegraspeciesLatreille, 1828Trapezia integraLatreille,1828, anyway. We believe that our present action best serves the interest of longterm nomenclatural stability.

To this effect and to maintain stability, we hereby designate theneotype ofAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetraliafulvaspeciesSerene, 1984Tetralia fulvaSerène,1984, designated byCastro (1997 a:65), a male (MNHN­B25234; cl 7.3 mm, cw 8.4 mm) from HeronIsland (23 º26 ’N,151 º55 ’E), Queensland,Australia, as the simultaneousneotype ofAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaCancridaeCancerglaberrimusspeciesHerbst, 1790Cancer glaberrimus Herbst,1790. We also designate this specimen as theneotype forAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTrapeziidaeTrapeziaintegraspeciesLatreille, 1828Trapezia integraLatreille,1828,AnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTrapeziidaeTrapeziaserratifronsspeciesJacquinot, 1846Trapezia serratifrons Jacquinot,1846, andAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaTetraliidaeTetralialaevissimaspeciesStimpson, 1858Tetralia laevissimaStimpson,1858. This action effectively makes all five names objective synonyms ofAnimaliaMalacostracaDecapodaCancridaeCancerglaberrimusspeciesHerbst, 1790C. glaberrimus Herbst,1790.
